Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 02:36PM GointoCarolina wrote: The only real reason not to wait is the stress of worrying and wondering.I had one breast surgeon do the biopsy,but he was a little too nonchalant and uncaring to suit me,so I chose another who did my surgery.We have a breast care center and they get you in for a biopsy within 24 hours.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 06:53AM GointoCarolina wrote: Thank you so much ,I know I am just worrying over everything.Thank God you all are here to help me through this.Jackie
Posts.Title: Port question: Catheter from neck to port GointoCarolina bluedasher

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 12:50PM GointoCarolina wrote: Do have it checked.Is there a breast care center near you? They will be kind and compassionate and will see you quickly.
Posts.Title: Am I just being silly to worry? 85Laura suzanneinphoenix

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 10:49AM GointoCarolina wrote: I am a ways out and my hair is still very dry.The only thing I can use for shampoo is something I make myself..I buy foaming bath butter and whip different oils into it,jojoba,sweet almond, emu,whatever.If you do a search for foaming bath butter,you will find where to buy it and the recipes to make it.Or PM me and I will give you the info.It is very easy,you just use an electric mixer.You can add whatever scent you want.A friend of mine uses it too and she loves it,says it makes her hair very soft and shiny.She is nagging me to make her more as her supply is getting low!For conditioner I use Giovanni Hair Reconstructor.
Posts.Title: What products did you use on your hair after chemo sheuber lrr4993

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 04:56PM GointoCarolina wrote: If you feel conflicted,I think you would be happier if you did not have immediate recon.I had a uni mast originally,my remaining breast was large,wearing a prothesis was a pain,wearing no bra was a bigger pain.I now have a double mast but after a year of being flat,I am going to have recon.My regret is that I did not have the bilateral mast initially,but I do not regret delaying recon.I do not regret seeing how it worked for me being flat.Some women are OK with it,I found out I am not.I have spent so much time researching and reading posts here,I feel comfortable with my decision.That is the important thing with all this,do what you feel inside you is right.And I do have to add that the majority of recon pictures are taken early on before the scars have faded and some are taken before the breasts have been adjusted for symmetry.If you want to see recon pictures and info by the women who have had it done,(not a surgeon's website) ask for permission to access TimTam's site.Good luck in whatever you decide..and don't feel rushed!!
Posts.Title: satisfaction with mastectomy only - no recontruction Papyrus 11BC

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 03:23PM GointoCarolina wrote: Thank you so much for posting this.I went to a different hospital for my last mammo.The doctor who read it was worried that my breast was so dense and said with my past diagnosis I should be having MRIs. I had been researching reconstruction and had pretty much decided I would have bilateral....your story convinced me.Bless that little techs heart.
Posts.Title: My story--a mam.tech saved my life Joanne58 Joanne58

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 03:54PM GointoCarolina wrote: WOW!I found this thread at the right time..have an appointment tomorrow about recon and all I could think of was having to take my clothes off and have this nice looking younger man look at the lumpy bumpy me...I have been trying to exercise,but some days....And I was feeling guilty because my best friend is taking me and we always go to lunch..and I planned  to eat healthy,but what kind of celebration is that???..Thanks to you,tomorrow I am just going to enjoy,have my wine,eat chocolate cake..and maybe say to the doctor"Honey,if you had only seen me naked five years ago..."
Posts.Title: I'm fially coming out of the closet as a slouch. weesa faithfulheart

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 10:00AM GointoCarolina wrote: They are a berry that can make sour foods tatse sweet.What my friend read said that they help with the metallic taste that can be a chemo side effect,they do not make foods taste sweet,but take away the metallic taste and the food tastes normal.I saw them a while ago on one of the morning shows, they ate one and then ate fresh lemon and said it was sweet.Jackie
Posts.Title: Miracle Berries...Has anyone tried? GointoCarolina GointoCarolina

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 09:09AM GointoCarolina wrote: If your mother does not feel comfortable with this surgeon, definitely find another.I found a lump, had mammogram and was rushed the next day to what is supposed to be the best breast cancer center in our area.I met with a surgeon, who neither my friend who went with me or I  really liked,thought maybe it was because we were stressed,but his answer to ouir questions were flippant and abrupt.Had him do the biopsy.He seemed in a hurry during the biopsy, and then came rushing back in as I was getting dressed to say he had forgotten to look at lymph nodes with the ultrasound.A nurse called me three days later to tell me the biopsy was positive for cancer, but I could not see the surgeon for over ten days as he was on vacation. They never offered to have me see anyone else in their facility.I had heard of a surgeon quite a ways from us and went to him.I loved him, he was gentle and caring,never made me feel rushed.It is extremely important that you feel comfortable with all the doctors involved in this journey.My sentinel node biopsy was all done the day of surgery,results were back before I even really woke up.Another reason I chose this doctor,I did not want a second surgery for lymph nodes and wanted to know immediately how they tested. Trust your instincts on this. Jackie
Posts.Title: Need some help understanding.... enthused stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2011 10:49AM GointoCarolina wrote: CarylC,can you tell me how the Apostrophe bra is for size? I know some things can run large or small. I can't go shopping right now,so would have to order from the internet.Thanks!!

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 04:14PM GointoCarolina wrote: Just wanted to say,the back of my head really started hurting when I tried to put my head on a pillow.I mixed up some emu oil and Palmers cocoa butter, smeared it on my hair and into my scalp.In about a half hour,it no longer hurt. I have also stopped washing my hair daily as I know it was getting drier each time.Has anyone else tried cream or oils?Jackie

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 12:23PM GointoCarolina wrote: My hair is starting to fall out today,I had my first TCH 19 days ago.I was just outside combing my hair and letting the wind take it away,crying and saying good bye.It is mainly the back of my head right now,I will hope to keep some on the sides as others have done.Guess I will go shopping for hats!! Jackie

Posts.Content: May 5, 2009 12:45PM GointoCarolina wrote: I had a mastectomy and SNB and I too noticed the body odor.It is not a bad smell of infection, just a sweat smell! I told my surgeon and he said many women had told him about this.It does go away,I think maybe the sweat glands get riled up. Jackie
Posts.Title: BODY ODOR birenegn ghety

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 04:40AM GointoCarolina wrote: Did you have a mastectomy or a lumpectomy?  Grade three indicates that it is aggressive, are you HER positive? How large was the tumor? All of these play a factor in what therapies follow surgery.I had a mastectomy, clean margins, no nodes, ER/PR negative, but my tumor was over 2cm and HER positive, so I had chemo and will finish with my last herceptin October 1...YAY! Jackie
Posts.Title: NOT SURE IF I SHOULD DO CHEMO Boxergirl London-Virginia

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 07:38AM GointoCarolina wrote:  I had a uni mast...bilateral was not offered.The next year at my mammo,I got a letter saying I had a very dense breast.That combined with the fact that my remaining breast was so large and I was uncomfortable with a prosthesis made me decide to have a proph mast. I wish I had had a bilateral originally and spared mysef the additilonal surgery.
Posts.Title: Surgery, dense breasts, HER2+ and me Bippy625 knmtwins

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 05:38PM GointoCarolina wrote: I am wondering if I can join this group? I had my mastectomy for cancer back in September 2008,but I am scheduled for a prophylactic mastectomy on February 21.I honestly do not remember much about my first mast,I was still in shock over the cancer diagnosis.The doctor told me this time I will have less pain as no nodes will be removed and she will let me go home the same night.I am planning to have microfat grafting for my recon..anxious to put the last few years behind me and start fresh!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 06:16PM GointoCarolina wrote: I have been where you all are and I so wish we were not meeting like this.It is scary and lonely,no matter how much family and friends you have,they can never understand what it is like to be in our shoes.I am so thankful that I have had this forum,I just wish I had found it sooner.Since I have been through it,except radiation, maybe I can help some of you with info.I never even thought of reconstruction when I was diagnosed and after my mastectomy,I thought I would be fine with a prothesis.As I went through chemo and herceptin,I didn't even care if I was uneven or not! But I finally got feeling better and I now miss wearing my old clothes.Can't wear a prothesis as my nerves regenerated on my scar and any pressure hurts.I gave very serious thought to SGAP recon,but knew the long surgery and recovery were just not right for me,I have had enough down time! Then I found out about the fat grafting.I am lucky to be close enough to Boston that I can have it done,if 5 or 6 hours is close!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: May 15, 2010 06:48AM GointoCarolina wrote: When I was diagnosed, I never even thought of recon....I just wanted the cancer OUT of me...I chose mastectomy as I knew I did not want radiation.I have a friend now who has BC,she was diagnosed in December 2009,went through four lumpectomies and excisions as she was so desperate to not lose her breast.Now she has to have a mastectomy and is delaying it while she researches recon.Also sounds like chemo is in the cards for her,though her onco score was only ten.I have tried to help her do research and I have read nothing that will convince me that recon is right for me..too much pain, too long under anesthesia,too long a recovery period and then when things go wrong,sounds like they really go wrong.Plus I read of women who are so dissatisfied after doing it,it does not meet their expectations.I was always vain of my breasts and hair..go figure...but no way would I put myself and my body through more surgery to replace a part of my body that is basically useless.I do have to wear a prothesis as my remaining breast needs the support of a bra and the bra is very uncomfortabloe for me with no form..if not for that,I would not wear one.I wear the form for my own comfort,not for society.I am lucky,my husband is so supportive,but if he wasn't,he would be out the door.
Posts.Title: What made you decide not to recon lucylou 3jaysmom

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 05:01PM GointoCarolina wrote: Thanks so much for sharing this.I didn't have nodes taken this time,but mine bothered me for a long time after.I have some swelling on the front down over my ribs.My PS said it is normal because I had so much trauma in such a short time,I not only had the expanders put in and removed,but all the Alloderm.I was taking Aleve and it helped a lot..but I still have problems with my stomach from chemo and started having pain, so had to stop taking it.I will try massaging the scars,I am such a wimp about touching any place that hurts.When I had my first mastectomy I had to go to PT and he would massage those scars for me.....I will make an appointment to see him next week..thanks again!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 12:16PM GointoCarolina wrote: I had a mastectomy because I did not want radiation.Jackie
Posts.Title: Mastectomy VS Lumpectomy yunlee72 PiscesMoon

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 01:58PM GointoCarolina wrote: Gosh,you are so much like me,I could have written this post..except for the losing weight part!!I have been feeling so ugly,I have never had short hair and havn't been flat since before 6th grade.My husband's birthday is next week,we have plans to go out.My usual outfit would have been jeans,a low cut cleavage revealing(tasteful) tank and a cute jacket or shirt.I used to wear my beautiful antique necklaces, but have not wanted to draw attention to my flatness and port scar.I started trying on clothes and ended up blatting..I feel like an ugly man...Then a package arrived in the mail,it was  a pair of microbead breasts forms...I put on a bra that does not hurt on my ribs( I am still very tender from surgery in April and I was afraid the forms would hurt on my chest) I stuck in the forms....they didn't hurt!!!............I went to the mirror and there I was blatting again..but this time because it looked like the girls were back!!!I have no cleavage,I am OK with that for now,but just to know I can wear some of my old favorite clothes is a blessing to me.I am still planning recon,microfat grafting,because like you,no way am I into a lengthy surgery and recovery,been there,done that.But now I can get through the summer and feel a little bit more like me.I am sure you could manage these forms,I hate most mastectomy bras anyway,they are ugly and uncomfortable and expensive.So while I can't say I am loving the chest I have right now,at least the clothes struggle is over..now I have to find a talented hair dresser...and lose a few pounds...I was pretty much feeling like giving up on trying to look good....who knew these two little puffs could change all that!!
Posts.Title: How Long Does It Take...? Lena Lena

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2010 04:58PM GointoCarolina wrote: Oh,I just found this thread and Kristen I had my mastectomy in Syracuse! Can you give me more info on your physical therapist? Mine is great and I know he would be willing to be in touch with yours for ideas to help me.Or I am willing to travel for help.Thank you so much.I am so glad I found this!!!
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 07:35AM GointoCarolina wrote: Thank you both so much.The doctor I am seeing is my PC not the doctor who did the surgery.When I said concerned,I meant he really cares that I am so tired and wants to see me so I can talk to him and not be worried.I really do not have much of an appetite,so I am sure he is going to address that.I am making myself eat,but I am usually planning my next meal! Hearing from both of you really helps.I think part of my problem is boredom and anxiety that I will never feel better,I am always busy,I don't work but have a lot of pets and love to work outside in the yard.Yesterday I started very gentle walking for 5 minutes each hour and I think that helped,I was so inactive while I had the drains.Thank you again,it helps so much to be reassured by others who understand.
Posts.Title: Post surgery fatigue questions GointoCarolina GointoCarolina

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 11:06AM GointoCarolina wrote: Thanks,SpecialK....that makes sense about the anesthesia...it took me about a month to recover from my first mastectomy and I was under for about 4 hours.So I will listen to my poor old body!I have been doing my best with the protein,my husband made chili  and that seemed to give me a boost and my friend sent me over some of that instant breakfast powder....that helped me get back on my feet after chemo.I am sure it is filled with junk,but what isn't these days? I love my skim milk and yogurt,so think I am doing OK in that area.I do have damage to my digestive system from chemo,so have to supplement daily with B vitamins...which I forgot to take with me and had no time to buy any..then the surgery and was not even thinking about it...so I am sure that is playing a part.It is so kind of you all to take time to write,it really helps me emotionally and that of course helps physically!
Posts.Title: Post surgery fatigue questions GointoCarolina GointoCarolina

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 04:00PM GointoCarolina wrote: I see that this thread is very sensitive,so I hope I do not step on toes.My husband is perfectly fine with whatever I choose.....which is how it should be.Who matters in this is me.....sound selfish.....maybe.....but I am the one who had a life and body and health changing experience.I have been totally flat for one year......l had a proph mast last year.I HATE being flat.My breasts were a large(pun intended) part of me.I cannot summon up the desire to have sex,partly because my chest is so sensitive,uncomfortably so.I am trying to plan for recon(flap surgery) and my insurance is putting up road blocks every step of the way.I envy those of you who are OK with being flat,I truly wish I could wrap my head around it for myself,it would be so much easier.I wonder why you are so angry at the women posting who have had recon,they said it is up to you to decide what is right for you.If you are happy being flat,why does it bother you ? And as soon as my insurance approves it,I will get recon too....In the meantime, I check in here and sometimes get helpful hints.This forum is for women who are waiting for recon too,not just those who have totally decided against it.But I often feel since I am  not  anti recon,that I am not welcome and so I rarely post.
Posts.Title: What does your husband/loved one think about your flatness? otter otter

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 02:28PM GointoCarolina wrote: I have no regret over having my original mast and my proph mast.And for a while I was fine having no breasts,I bought new bras and forms and thought this is good,even though I could not wear them for extended periods..Over the summer,that all changed..I missed wearing my cute tops,I missed my cleavage,I missed my breasts.A friend took me shopping and I tried on outfit after outfit and came home with a few that helped me feel better.But my breasts were one of my vanities.My chest is ugly and painful,I now walk leaning back.I am going to start physical therapy soon.But I am 99.9% sure I am going to have recon.I know the majority of you on this thread are happy with no recon and I wish I was.If recon was not an option,I would have to wrap my head around it and accept the new me.But it would be a long hard road and I have had enough.I am tired of being reminded every time I take a shower or change my clothes of what I have been through.I know reconstructed breasts will not be like the ones I had,but I am ready for reasonable facsimiles that are permanently attached.
